James West.Action: Hears the clatter of approaching wagons while bathing and immediately stops and peeks out the knothole, showing awareness and readiness.
Engages in a tender kiss with the Saloon Girl and speaks in a friendly, familiar manner.
Peeks out the knothole surreptitiously while continuing the kiss, suggesting secretive or distracted behavior.
Surreptitiously peeks out the knothole while maintaining the kiss, surveilling the approaching wagons without alerting others.
Expresses concern about safety by warning the Saloon Girl about the knothole possibly causing harm if it rains.
Gently corrects the Saloon Girl's attempt to fix the hole by suggesting she use her own clothes instead of his, revealing a playful yet considerate nature.
Breaks the kiss abruptly upon hearing the creak indicating danger, prioritizing caution over personal affection.
Defends against racial slur firmly, calls out disrespect with clear stance.
Protects modesty by using hat to cover himself, encouraging modesty from Saloon Girl.
Light teasing, friendly banter with Saloon Girl about getting pants.
Maintains composure after a fall, calmly assesses situation, and uses wit while recovering his clothes under unexpected circumstances.

Successfully fights off guards with quick, efficient moves without unnecessary aggression.
Catches the falling, naked, screaming Saloon Girl gently, showing concern for her safety.
Asks for privacy politely amid a fight.
Catches the falling, naked, screaming Saloon Girl in his arms calmly and gallantly puts her down.

Calmly catches the falling, naked, screaming Saloon Girl in his arms despite the chaotic situation.
Quickly jumps up, grabs the overhead block and tackle system, and slides through the warehouse to pursue evidence.

Makes a light-hearted, slightly inappropriate remark about the lack of towels while in a tense situation.
Spots danger and attempts to steady glass vials in an unstable, dangerous situation, risking himself to stop an accident.
Yells firmly at horses to stop them from overturning the wagon, using physical effort and persistence to control a dangerous situation.
Shows a bitter smile and sarcastic commentary about the day's events, indicating frustration but also a resigned, somewhat friendly tone.
Bursts through the window to save Gordon/Dora from a knife attack, disarms McGrath in one smooth move, and offers a gallant smile while kindly addressing Gordon/Dora.
Quickly pats down McGrath, removes revolver and bag of gold coins efficiently.
Sticks the barrel of his gun in McGrath's ear to control the situation, showing assertiveness and tactical thinking.
Pushes off McGrath after being attacked and reacts quickly to avoid being shot.
Allows McGrath to lunge at him possibly leading to a melee, which may indicate a momentary lapse in anticipating enemy moves.
Uncorks a lethal kick to stop a fleeing attacker, protecting Gordon and attempting to stop the escape.
Tries to push Gordon aside aggressively, insisting she move out of the way.
Shows reflexive suspicion when Gordon acts strangely, initially drawing his gun out of caution.
Spots McGrath trying to escape and reacts with a lethal kick, sending a thug flying, actively engaging the enemy under pressure.
Tries to push Gordon aside to chase the fleeing enemy and asserts his authority as U.S. Army, showing determination and confidence.
Momentarily confused when Gordon removes a wig and reveals a badge, blinking at the unexpected disguise.
Oblivious to the impending disaster caused by the nitro wagon exploding downstairs.
Maintains calm and focus by questioning 'So now what...?' showing readiness to act despite not foreseeing the disaster.
Walks confidently into the White House despite obstacles, indicating self-assurance and respect for his own position.
Uses quick wit and a sawed-off shotgun to defuse a threatening situation without violence.
Does not escalate conflict further after showing strength, showing controlled and measured behavior.
Ignores or is indifferent to the astonishment or dislike of the house detectives.
Confidently dismounts and heads into the White House despite a sore leg, showing physical resilience and determination.

Faces house detectives who attempt to stop him; he skillfully uses misdirection by pretending to reach for his gun but instead draws a hidden sawed-off shotgun, taking them by surprise and defusing the situation.
Replies politely to President Grant's offer of drink and cigar.
Shows frustration and anger over letting General McGrath get away.
Draws a gun and places it against President Grant's head to test him, then fires a warning shot at the ceiling.
Draws his gun and places it against the President's head to test his identity and follows through with a warning shot to the ceiling.
Complains about losing General McGrath due to Artemus Gordon's interference, showing awareness of mission failure factors but also frustration.
Nods at Gordon's class ring as a sign of recognition and lowered his gun, showing a non-hostile approach toward Artemus Gordon.
Pokes a hole in the fake Presidential paunch with a bayonet, causing a flatulent noise and smirks afterward, which irritates Gordon.
Follows his typical aggressive 'shoot first' approach despite being advised otherwise by President Grant, showing stubbornness and insensitivity to teamwork.
Nods at Gordon's class ring identifying shared knowledge, lowering gun to de-escalate situation.

Intervenes quickly to identify the threat from McGrath and expresses determination to stop it.
Cuts off Gordon's suggestion to rely on Intelligence, insisting on acting immediately based on his own judgment.
Identifies McGrath as the threat immediately and insists on urgent action without waiting for intelligence.
Cuts off Gordon when he tries to introduce intelligence reports, implying distrust or impatience with formal procedures.
Glowers at Gordon, impatient and dismissive when Gordon tries to explain his invention.
Snaps off a smug salute and quickly rides off, leaving Gordon behind without encouragement.
Quickly mounts his horse and spurs it into a fast departure to catch the train, showing decisiveness.
Shakes his head in disgust at the new invention (the motorized bicycle) instead of engaging with or considering its potential.
Displays a smug salute and confident attitude when leaving, indicating self-assurance.
Behaves urgently and purposefully while Gordon is slow and distracted.

Fails to interrupt Gordon’s calm composure and control over the situation, who continues sewing undisturbed.

Clings for dear life under the train car, showing vulnerability but determination.

Expresses shock and disbelief upon seeing a severed human head.
Engages calmly in deciding destination and lets Gordon suggest involving Professor Morton.
Confidently states destination as New Orleans when questioned, showing decisiveness in an uncertain situation.
Reacting with disbelief and repeatedly acknowledging the severed head without taking immediate control or showing problem-solving initiative.
Identifies man's head and confidently asserts recognition of McGrath from the image.
Places bifocals on Morton's nose to clarify the blurry image, enabling progress in investigation.
Realizes the image projected on the wall is upside down due to lens refraction and correctly interprets the fuzzy image as McGrath, confirming his previous suspicion.
Identifies the problem with the blurry image and solves it by putting bifocals on the head, thereby focusing the image to reveal important information.
Refuses to play subservient role sarcastically and with clear disdain, asserting his own dignity.
Openly asserts his identity and personal standards with confidence in front of a friend.
Plans to infiltrate disguised as a government agent aiming to kill an enemy, showing determination and protective intent.

Reluctantly touches Gordon's fake breasts when challenged, showing some tolerance.

Demonstrates confidence by openly challenging Gordon's disguise and making clear, decisive observations about its flaws.

Draws pistol into Gordon's face but in a lighthearted way, jokes about convenience of pockets.

Draws pistol quickly and confidently when surprised, demonstrating readiness and situational awareness.

Engages in light banter about convenience of pocket for gun vs. notepad, showing confidence, composure, and mental agility.

Attempts to navigate a potentially dangerous social situation by engaging in polite conversation and seeking an old friend at the party.

Scans the crowd to identify familiar persons, displaying vigilance and situational awareness.

Responds to Loveless's greeting with a measured, somewhat respectful remark: 'Well, when a man comes back from the dead, it's an occasion to stand and be counted.'

Considers stepping over the fence but respects Gordon's warning and does not move when Gordon grabs his leg.

Is about to step over the suspicious fence despite not knowing the full danger, showing some recklessness or lack of caution.
Stops Gordon from stepping forward rashly, showing restraint and tactical thinking in a tense situation.

Recognizes that Loveless's foot is powerless due to a punctured hydraulic tube and uses that advantage to free himself from under Loveless's foot.
Calmly rubs his neck to regain circulation after being pinned down, showing composure under pressure.
Makes a witty remark to diffuse tension, indicating confidence and control over the situation.
Encourages Loveless to stay strong despite his defeat, mocking him playfully rather than showing cruelty.
Mocks Loveless’s crippled state by imitating his accent and using sarcastic encouragement.
Confidently confronts Loveless after tracking him for four years, shows verbal taunting that reflects psychological control.
Notices Loveless's shotgun armrests and immediately reacts by leaping to grab an I-beam overhead, narrowly avoiding gunfire.
Shows quick situational awareness as the shotgun blasts puncture a pipe causing steam to spew, indicating potential leverage over the environment.
Jumps up quickly to grab a girder when the wheelchair spins and wedges into the railing, preventing a fall off the cliff.
Free-falls through the belly of the Tarantula and instinctively grabs onto the back of Loveless' wheelchair, saving both from falling off the cliff.
Uses humor and calm reassurance to ease Loveless' fear despite their dangerous predicament.
Grabs the joystick to take decisive action against Loveless, expressing strong desire to see him dead.
Laughs vindictively while hanging on the Knife Guy's ankles after forcing Loveless into a dangerous fall.
Decisively grabs the joystick from Loveless to take control of the situation, acting decisively under pressure.
Uses physical skill and fearlessness by grabbing onto the Chain and hanging by his ankles after the fall, showing confidence and capability.
Receives Secret Service badge from President Grant alongside Gordon, sharing moment of honor and trust.
Receives Secret Service badge and recognition from President Grant, indicating trust and confidence in his abilities.
Celebrates the successful completion of the railroad and foiling of Loveless' plot.
Engages politely and confidently with Rita, expresses genuine concern and interest in her well-being and plans.
Fails to anticipate or uncover Rita's true relationship status before revelation, showing naivety or lack of investigative thoroughness.
Engages in a moment of reflection acknowledging Rita's remark about loyalty and companionship.
Casually dismisses Rita leaving by saying 'there's a lot of other women in the world.'
Neither West nor Gordon knows what to say when confronted by Rita's comment.
Rides slowly into the sunset with Gordon astride the imposing Tarantula device, displaying calmness and confidence.
